items.title: Accept markdown long descriptions
items.body:
If a setup configuration tells `long_description_content_type="text/markdown"`, then the long description should be checked for Markdown validity instead of ReST validity.

For example in pospell:
https://github.com/JulienPalard/pospell/blob/master/setup.py#L13

PyPI renders it correctly:
https://pypi.org/p/pospell

But pyroma whines:
```
pyroma .
------------------------------
Checking .
Found pospell
------------------------------
Your long_description is not valid ReST: 
<string>:41: (ERROR/3) Unexpected indentation.
<string>:39: (WARNING/2) Inline literal start-string without end-string.
<string>:52: (WARNING/2) Inline emphasis start-string without end-string.
<string>:55: (WARNING/2) Inline strong start-string without end-string.
<string>:55: (WARNING/2) Inline emphasis start-string without end-string.
<string>:57: (WARNING/2) Option list ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.
<string>:59: (WARNING/2) Definition list ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.
<string>:59: (WARNING/2) Inline literal start-string without end-string.
<string>:59: (WARNING/2) Inline interpreted text or phrase reference start-string without end-string.
------------------------------
Final rating: 9/10
Cottage Cheese
------------------------------
```

items.title: Missing pygments dependency in setup.py
items.body:
Pyroma needs pygments, but it is not automatically installed when installing pyroma. Is it the wanted behavior? It looks better to me to have it installed automatically, by adding the dependency to pyroma in setup.py.

BTW, thanks for your project.

Here is the process to reproduce:
```bash
 vincent  vincent-portable  tmp  pyro  $  python3.7 -m venv venv

    100% |████████████████████████████████| 358kB 3.7MB/s 
Requirement already satisfied: setuptools in ./venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages (from pyroma) (40.8.0)
Collecting docutils (from pyroma)
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/36/fa/08e9e6e0e3cbd1d362c3bbee8d01d0aedb2155c4ac112b19ef3cae8eed8d/docutils-0.14-py3-none-any.whl

Found python-dev-tools

items.title: Don't mark down when known Trove licence present +`license` omitted
items.body:
According to https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#license:

> The ``license`` argument doesn't have to indicate the license under
> which your package is being released, although you may optionally do
> so if you want.  If you're using a standard, well-known license, then
> your main indication can and should be via the ``classifiers``
> argument. Classifiers exist for all major open-source licenses.
> 
>  The "license" argument is more typically used to indicate differences
> from well-known licenses, or to include your own, unique license. As a
> general rule, it's a good idea to use a standard, well-known license,
> both to avoid confusion and because some organizations avoid software
> whose license is unapproved.

This was added in https://github.com/pypa/packaging.python.org/pull/492 to "indicate that this argument is meant for deviations from the Trove classifier, not instead of it".

# Actual result

If a project has a known Trove licence and the `license` classifier, it gets 10/10.

If the redundant `license` is removed, it's marked down to 9/10.

# Expected result

Instead, pyroma should give 10/10 if there's a known Trove licence and no `license` argument. It should be marked down if it has both.

If the Trove licence is something like `License :: Other/Proprietary License`, it should be 10/10 when there is a `license` explaining what is being used, and marked down when `license` is missing.

items.title: pyroma changes sys.argv, and restoring fails
items.body:
This is when using `pyroma` as `zest.releaser` plugin, and is noticeable when using other plugins that try to use `sys.argv`.
See https://github.com/collective/zestreleaser.towncrier/issues/6#issuecomment-469409035.

Fix seems to be simple. In https://github.com/regebro/pyroma/blob/2.4/pyroma/projectdata.py#L110 change this:

    save_argv = sys.argv

to this:

    save_argv = sys.argv.copy()

(Or use `deepcopy(sys.argv)`, but `copy` seems to be enough.)
I will create a PR.

items.title: The long_description ReST test passes even if it's not valid ReST
items.body: This is because rendering invalid text no longer raises an error, fixing this requires docutils digging.

items.title: pyroma should not warn about license if the license is specified in classifiers
items.body:
> The `license` argument doesn’t have to indicate the license under which your package is being released, although you may optionally do so if you want. If you’re using a standard, well-known license, then your main indication can and should be via the classifiers argument. Classifiers exist for all major open-source licenses.
https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#license

items.title: Check for Development Status classifier
items.body:
I think it is a good indicator to evaluate a package. Consider adding it to the checks.
With such a check you would have seen that it is missing in your own package (https://github.com/regebro/pyroma/issues/25)!

items.title: DeprecationWarnings in Python 3
items.body:
Running this code:
```python
import pyroma

print("Get data")
data = pyroma.projectdata.get_data(".")

print("Get rating")
rating = pyroma.ratings.rate(data)

print("Done")
```

With deprecation warnings enabled is good in Python 2.7.14:
```console
$ python2 -W default::DeprecationWarning pyroma-test.py
Get data
Get rating
Done
```

But there's two warnings in Python 3.6.4:
```console
$ python3 -W default::DeprecationWarning pyroma-test.py
Get data
/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/depends.py:2: DeprecationWarning: the imp module is deprecated in favour of importlib; see the module's documentation for alternative uses
  import imp
Get rating
/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/docutils/io.py:245: DeprecationWarning: 'U' mode is deprecated
  self.source = open(source_path, mode, **kwargs)
Done
```

items.title: Start suggesting people add `project_urls` to setup.py
items.body:
There's a new-ish [setuptools](https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html) option [project_urls](https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#project-urls) that will be displayed by the new https://pypi.org/ in a sidebar.  One can use this to link to a bugtracker, documentation, source control repository etc.

Perhaps it would be a good idea for pyroma to start suggesting people add `project_urls` to their setup.py files?

items.title: [Question] zip_safe setting if Wheels
items.body:
### 1. Briefly

I'm not sure, is the parameter `zip_safe` needs, **if** developer build package use [**Wheels**](https://pythonwheels.com/).

### 2. Steps to reproduce

I create my Python package → [**I build my package, use Wheels**](https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#platform-wheels):

    python setup.py bdist_wheel

I publish my package to PyPI use [**Twine**](https://github.com/pypa/twine):

    twine upload dist/*

I install my package use pip:

    pip install <my_package>

### 3. Essence of the question

**If** I build my package, use `python setup.py sdist`, `zip_safe` parameter have a meaning:

**If** `zip_safe = True`:

    package add to my `site-packages` directory, packed to `.egg` format;

**else**:

    package add to `site-packages` directory unpacked.

**But if** I build my package, use `python setup.py sdist`, I get same behavior **for** `zip_safe` `true` **and** `false` **or if** I don't have `zip_safe` parameter. Package add to `site-packages` directory unpacked.

### 4. pyroma

**If** I have line `zip_safe = True` or `zip_safe = False`:

```
D:\SashaCanelo>pyroma .
------------------------------
Checking .
Registered VCS backend: git
Registered VCS backend: hg
Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Registered VCS backend: svn
Registered VCS backend: bzr
Found sashacanelo
------------------------------
Final rating: 10/10
Your cheese is so fresh most people think it's a cream: Mascarpone
------------------------------

```

**else**:

```
D:\SashaCanelo>pyroma .
------------------------------
Checking .
Registered VCS backend: git
Registered VCS backend: hg
Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Registered VCS backend: svn
Registered VCS backend: bzr
Found sashacanelo
------------------------------
You are using Setuptools or Distribute but do not specify if this package is zip_safe or not. You should specify it, as it defaults to True, which you probably do not want.
------------------------------
Final rating: 9/10
Cottage Cheese
------------------------------
```

But I think, that `zip_safe` parameter is excessive in this case.

Thanks.

items.title: [Question] Continuous integration behavior
items.body:
### 1. Summary

My pyroma Final rating:

1. Local — 10/10,
1. Travis CI — 9/10,
1. AppVeyor — 0/10,
1. CircleCI — 0/10.

### 2. Local environment

+ Windows 10 Enterprise LTSB 64-bit EN,
+ Python 3.6.4,
+ pyroma 2.3.

### 3. Configuration

See my `Readme.rst`, `requirements.txt`, `setup.cfg`, `setup.py`, `.travis.yml`, `appveyor.yml` and `circle.yml` in [**test repository**](https://github.com/Kristinita/SashaPyromaDebugging).

I add [**flake8**](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/flake8), [**pydocstyle**](http://www.pydocstyle.org/) and [**vulture**](https://github.com/jendrikseipp/vulture) in CI `yml` files, to demonstrate, that another tools correct works for me in Continuous Integration.

### 4. Steps to reproduce

In root folder of my repository I run:

    pyroma .

### 5. Expected behavior

Local:

```
D:\SashaPyromaDebugging>pyroma .
------------------------------
Checking .
Registered VCS backend: git
Registered VCS backend: hg
Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Config variable 'Py_DEBUG' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect
Config variable 'WITH_PYMALLOC' is unset, Python ABI tag may be incorrect

Registered VCS backend: svn
Registered VCS backend: bzr
Found erichek
------------------------------
Final rating: 10/10
Your cheese is so fresh most people think it's a cream: Masc
```

### 6. CI behavior

+ [**Travis CI**](https://travis-ci.org/Kristinita/SashaPyromaDebugging/builds/336832977),
+ [**AppVeyor**](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Kristinita/sashapyromadebugging/build/1.0.1),
+ [**CircleCI**](https://circleci.com/gh/Kristinita/SashaPyromaDebugging/1).

Thanks.

items.title: [Feature request] Continuous integration support
items.body:
### 1. Request

It would be nice, if pyroma will support continuous integration services as [**Travis CI**](https://travis-ci.org/) and [**AppVeyor**](https://www.appveyor.com/).

### 2. Argumentation

Error reporting in `setup.py` and/or `setup.cfg` in continuous integration process.

### 3. Example

my example `.travis-yml` file:

```yaml
language: python
python:
  - "3.6.4"
install:
  - pip install pyroma
script:
  - pyroma .
```

**If** `Final rating: 10/10`:

    build passed.

**else**:

    build failed.

Thanks.

items.title: Pyroma installation fails if LC_ALL is set to en_US.ascii
items.body:
Error:
`Downloading pyroma-2.3.tar.gz (345kB)", " Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:", " Traceback (most recent call last):", " File \"<string>\", line 1, in <module>", " File \"/tmp/pip-build-79vf1ldo/pyroma/setup.py\", line 8, in <module>", " long_description=open(\"README.rst\", 'rt').read() + \"\\n\" +", " File \"/srv/pyramid/kjvrvg/venv/lib/python3.5/encodings/ascii.py\", line 26, in decode", " return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]", " UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 3516: ordinal not in range(128)", " ", " ----------------------------------------"], "warnings": []}`

That was introduced in the version 2.3 release.

items.title: Parsing error `<string>:1: (WARNING/2) Inline strong start-string without end-string.`
items.body:
`setup.cfg`:

    [metadata]
    name = pp
    long_description = file: README.mkd

`README.mkd`:

    # title
    **a**bc **d**ef **h**ij.

Command: `pyroma .`

Output:

    Checking .
    Found pp
    <string>:1: (WARNING/2) Inline strong start-string without end-string.
    <string>:1: (WARNING/2) Inline strong start-string without end-string.
    <string>:1: (WARNING/2) Inline strong start-string without end-string.
    ------------------------------
    ... (normal pyroma output)

I searched this error on the web, it appears in many projects, probably du to the `**a**b` scheme, that would allow to give weight to only the first letter of the word `ab`, but is somehow not handled by some widely-used parser.
I did not found anything about that hypothetical parser.

items.title: Accept alternate readthedocs.org domain names
items.body:
[According to your code](https://github.com/regebro/pyroma/blob/2035d4bb411236f09860166f91c0cee8e0489b42/pyroma/pypidata.py#L15), the only accepted domain name for documentation is http://readthedocs.org. However, other valid domain names are available (see the [readthedocs documentation](https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/alternate_domains.html#rtfd-org)): http://rtfd.io, http://rtfd.org, http://readthedocs.io.

Shouldn't these be accepted as well?

Regards,
-- Louis

items.title: More checks
items.body:
Thanks to Tarek I realized there are two more checks that should be done:

1. Tags should match other data, for example, if you have licence='MIT', the 'License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License' should also be included.
2. Requirements in setup.py and requirements.txt should match.
